data.title: The Thiers Government and the Outbreak of Civil War in France, February–April 1871
data.meta_description: The Thiers Government and the Outbreak of Civil War in France, February–April 1871 - Volume 23 Issue 4
data.text:
In the numerous works devoted to the French civil war of 1871, nothing has so much been taken for granted as the motives of the government during the six weeks that separated its taking office on 19 February and the outbreak of fighting on 2 April. Thiers and his colleagues are part of the myth of the Commune, the scribes and pharisees of the revolutionary passion play. They fill the roles well: there are few figures so unprepossessing in the history of nineteenth-century France.

1 Consequently, there are no recent scholarly biographies, even of so important a figure as Thiers. Malo, Henri, Thiers 1797–1877 (Paris, 1932)Google Scholar, detailed and pro-Thiers, gives no documentary references; Dreyfus, Robert, Monsieur Thiers contre l'empire, la guerre, la commune, 1869–1871 (Paris, 1928)Google Scholar, pedestrian and superficial, and Lucas-Dubreton, J., Aspects de Monsieur Thiers (Paris, 1948)Google Scholar, witty and penetrating, are based on secondary works and a few published sources. Works on other members of the government are even more limited.

3 At the Ministère des Affaires Etrangères (MAE), Archives Diplomatiques, section Papiers d'agents, ‘Papiers Thiers, Traité de Francfort, armée d'occupation 1871–73’ and ‘Papiers Jules Favre, Guerre’, vol. v (16 02–10 03 1871)Google Scholar and vol. VI (11 March–15 June). At the Bibliothèque Nationale (BN), Papiers A. Thiers, Correspondance 1871, n.a.fr. 20621–20623. At the Archives Historiques de Guerre (AHG), reports and despatches in Li, ‘Guerre de 1870–71, Armée de Paris’, cartons 118–21.

12 For the governmental view of these events see Vinoy, Gen. J., Campagne de 1870–1871, l'armistice et la Commune (Paris, 1872)Google Scholar; Simon, Jules, Le Gouvernement de M. Thiers, I (Paris, 1878)Google Scholar; Favre, Jules, Gouvernement de la Défense Nationale, III (Paris, 1875)Google Scholar; Thiers, Adolphe, Notes et souvenirs de M. Thiers 1870–1873 (Paris, 1901)Google Scholar; and statements to Enquête. For the view of the insurgents, Lissagaray, P.-O., Histoire de la Commune de 1871 (Paris, 1972), first published 1876Google Scholar, and Rougerie, Jacques, Paris libre 1871 (Paris, 1971)Google Scholar.

17 For views of deputies see, for example, de Meaux, Vicomte C., Souvenirs politiques 1871–1877 (Paris, 1905)Google Scholar; de Lacombe, Charles, Journal politique (Paris, 1907)Google Scholar; and de Marcère, M., L'Assemblée Nationale de 1871 (Paris, 1904)Google Scholar. See also the lively though sometimes misleading Brabant, F. H., The beginning of the Third Republic in France (London, 1940)Google Scholar and the amusingly malicious Bosq, Paul, Souvenirs de l' Assemblée Nationale 1871–1875 (Paris, 1908)Google Scholar.
